benefits.title: Dietary Reference Intakes for Calcium and Vitamin D
benefits.summary: Calcium and vitamin D play vital roles in bone health and overall health.

benefits.title: Osteoporosis: the role of micronutrients.
benefits.summary: Calcium and vitamin D supplementation has clear fracture benefits and is important for optimal bone health and preventing falls and fractures.
benefits.journal: The American journal of clinical nutrition

benefits.title: The role of calcium in peri- and postmenopausal women: 2006 position statement of the North American Menopause Society.
benefits.summary: Adequate calcium intake reduces bone loss and fractures in postmenopausal women, and has beneficial effects in nonskeletal disorders like hypertension, colorectal cancer, obesity, and nephrolithiasis.

benefits.title: Calcium Intake and Health
benefits.summary: Appropriate calcium intake reduces hypertensive disorders of pregnancy, lowers blood pressure, prevents osteoporosis, and lowers cholesterol values.

benefits.title: Calcium absorption and calcium bioavailability
benefits.summary: Calcium is important for bone health and its absorption consists of an active vitamin D-mediated component and a passive diffusional component.

benefits.title: The good, the bad, and the ugly of calcium supplementation: a review of calcium intake on human health
benefits.summary: Calcium intake is helpful in preventing and treating osteoporosis, but excessive intake might increase the risks of cardiovascular diseases.

benefits.title: Acute biochemical variations induced by four different calcium salts in healthy male volunteers
benefits.summary: Calcium supplements may reduce bone loss, non-vertebral fracture rates, and calcium citrate induces a significantly larger increase in serum calcium and suppression of serum PTH.

benefits.title: Applications of Calcium and its Supplement derived from Marine Organisms
benefits.summary: Calcium from marine organisms contributes to calcium absorption and bioavailability in the body, playing an important role in health and well-being.
benefits.journal: Critical Reviews in Food Science and Nutrition

benefits.title: Calcium Use in the Management of Osteoporosis: Continuing Questions and Controversies
benefits.summary: Calcium supplementation can reduce fracture risk, improve bone density, and improve bone turnover markers.

benefits.title: ADSA Foundation Lecture. Low calcium intake: the culprit in many chronic diseases.
benefits.summary: Increased calcium intake during growth and late postmenopause can prevent bone fragility, high blood pressure, and colon cancer.

side effects.title: Calcium Intake and Health
side effects.summary: Calcium supplementation side effects have been refuted, but may cause damage to iron status, renal stones, and myocardial infarction in older people.

side effects.title: Calcium supplements: benefits and risks
side effects.summary: Calcium supplements have a negative risk-benefit effect, with increased gastrointestinal side effects, renal calculi, and myocardial infarction risks, neutralizing any possible benefit in fracture prevention.

side effects.title: The good, the bad, and the ugly of calcium supplementation: a review of calcium intake on human health
side effects.summary: Excessive calcium intake might increase the risks of cardiovascular diseases, kidney stones, and gastrointestinal diseases.

side effects.title: Risk of Calcium Oxalate Nephrolithiasis after Calcium or Combined Calcium and Calcitriol Supplementation in Postmenopausal Women
side effects.summary: Calcium supplementation can cause hypercalciuria, but the risk of nephrolithiasis decreases rather than increase among subjects with higher calcium intake.

side effects.title: Calcium channel antagonists part IV: Side effects and contraindications drug interactions and combinations
side effects.summary: Calcium antagonists can cause minor side effects like flushing, headaches, constipation, and ankle edema, but serious side effects are rare and result from improper use.

side effects.title: Near‐Infrared‐Triggered Release of Ca2+ Ions for Potential Application in Combination Cancer Therapy
side effects.summary: Calcium ion is a potential therapeutic ion with manageable side effects and can trigger cell death in cancer cells upon near-infrared irradiation.

side effects.title: The Formation, Structural Characteristics, Absorption Pathways and Bioavailability of Calcium–Peptide Chelates
side effects.summary: Calcium supplements can have highly irritating effects on the stomach and are limited by low calcium content.

side effects.title: Calcium channel blockers: spectrum of side effects and drug interactions.
side effects.summary: Side effects of calcium antagonists include hypotension, conduction disturbances, bradycardia, tachycardia, headache, flush, constipation, diarrhea, and rare idiosyncratic side effects.

side effects.title: Analysis of oral fosfomycin calcium (Fosmicin) side-effects after marketing.
side effects.summary: Primary side-effects of oral fosfomycin calcium (FOM-Ca) include diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain, anorexia, eruption, and increased serum transaminase.
side effects.journal: International journal of clinical pharmacology, therapy, and toxicology

side effects.title: Calcium Intake Trend Over Time
side effects.summary: Excess calcium intake can lead to side effects like kidney stones and cardiovascular events.

dosage.title: Effect of low‐dose calcium supplements on bone loss in perimenopausal and postmenopausal Asian women: A randomized controlled trial
dosage.summary: A low-dose calcium supplement of 500 mg/d can effectively slow lumbar spine bone loss in perimenopausal and postmenopausal women with habitually low calcium intake.
dosage.journal: Journal of Bone and Mineral Research

dosage.title: Dose dependency of calcium absorption: A comparison of calcium carbonate and calcium citrate
dosage.summary: 0.5g of calcium is the optimum dose of either calcium salt, and calcium absorption is greater from 0.5g of calcium citrate than from 2.0g of calcium carbonate.
dosage.journal: Journal of Bone and Mineral Research

dosage.title: Calcium in the prevention of postmenopausal osteoporosis: EMAS clinical guide.
dosage.summary: The recommended daily intake of calcium varies between 700 and 1200mg of elemental calcium, depending on the endorsing source.

dosage.title: Does it make a difference how and when you take your calcium? The acute effects of calcium on calcium and bone metabolism.
dosage.summary: Small calcium doses (200 mg) taken 4 times/day decreased serum PTH and increased serum ionized calcium concentrations rapidly, with no significant effect on bone formation and resorption markers.
dosage.journal: The American journal of clinical nutrition

dosage.title: Long-term (6 months) cross-over comparison of calcium acetate with calcium carbonate as phosphate binder.
dosage.summary: Calcium acetate (CaAc) was given to 28 chronic hemodialysis patients at half the dose of elemental calcium (1,235 +/- 521 versus 2,375 +/- 1,470 mg/day).

dosage.title: 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D3-treated hypoparathyroidism: 35 patients years in 10 children.
dosage.summary: 1,25-(OH)2D3 treatment in hypoparathyroid children resulted in a mean ionized calcium level of 4.04-4.39 mg/dl.
dosage.journal: The Journal of clinical endocrinology and metabolism

dosage.title: Effects of increasing doses of 1α‐hydroxyvitamin D2 on calcium homeostasis in postmenopausal osteopenic women
dosage.summary: 1Î± hydroxyvitamin D2 doses range from 0.5 Î± g/day to 1Î2 g/day, with no significant changes in serum calcium levels.
dosage.journal: Journal of Bone and Mineral Research

dosage.title: IMPACT OF DOSING REGIMEN ON CONSUMPTION OF CALCIUM SUPPLEMENTS FOR PREVENTION OF PREECLAMPSIA AMONG ANTENATAL CARE CLIENTS: A CLUSTER‐RANDOMIZED, NON‐INFERIORITY TRIAL IN WESTERN KENYA
dosage.summary: The WHO guideline recommends 1.5–2.0 g/d of calcium supplementation for ante-natal prevention of pre-eclampsia.

dosage.title: Low-dosage micronized 17ß-estradiol prevents bone loss inpostmenopausal women
dosage.summary: Micronized 17 beta-estradiol has a continuous skeletal dose-response effect in the range of 0.5 to 2.0 mg, and calcium intake positively modifies the skeletal response to 1.0 mg.
dosage.journal: American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology

dosage.title: Randomized controlled trial of calcium supplementation in healthy, nonosteoporotic, older men.
dosage.summary: 1200 mg/d calcium supplementation has effects on bone mineral density in men comparable to those found in postmenopausal women, while 600 mg/d is ineffective for treating BMD.
